reporting-org.narrative: Ministry of Foreign Affairs of the Netherlands

description.narrative: The SRHR programme, with the largest pillar being Pro- gramme Conjoint (CARE, Cordaid, UNFPA and Rutgers) and a second pillar being PSI receiving support, ended 31 December 2020. For its follow-up programme, the Embassy seeks to sup- port innovative solutions that can effectively contribute to ad- dressing Burundi’s main SRHR challenges, i.e. the rapid popu- lation growth that causes demographic pressure on the coun- try's resources (land, food security, jobs etc.) and the high levels of sexual and gender-based violence. A multi-dimensional SRHR programme is required to pro- mote sustainable behavioural and normative change that achieve the intended impact (to turn around population growth and SGBV), reaching beyond the direct beneficiaries and be- yond project interventions. To achieve these changes in knowledge, attitude and practices, a strong focus on outcomes (as opposed to outputs) will be required while a holistic pro- gramming approach, created through collaborations and syn- ergies, will be key. Some first partners (BSF, PSI, HE) – that meet the criteria of offering innovative and effective solutions – have already been engaged. A remaining budget of EUR 15.600.000 is available for 2021-2024 to accommodate further innovative and effec- tive solutions. Whereas the earlier SRHR programme focused on three areas (health-education-community), the Embassy identified six areas of interventions that are interrelated and should go hand in hand to achieve the intended impact (to turn around population growth and SGBV): health, education, community, advocacy, mass communication, research. Tech- nology is seen as an important enabling solution and interconnecting force. Some of the components are expected to be (partially) catered for through other (central) funding. To support the holistic approach, the Embassy seeks to carry out a baseline study (as opposed to individual project base- lines). Upon selection of the partners, work will be carried out to jointly formulate a Theory of Change (ToC) and a joint re- sult framework, covering interventions in the foreseen areas. Close coordination between all partners is foreseen. An overall risk analysis is included in this general programme Bemo, but further risk analyses will be carried for the imple- menting partners for each specific project.
